metadata.title: A VIRTUAL REALITY ENVIRONMENT TO GUIDE MINIMALLY-INVASIVE INTRA-CARDIAC PROCEDURES RADIOTHERAPHY IGRT 4D CT: CURRENT STATUS AND FUTURE DIRECTIONS EVALUATION OF CONE BEAM CT DATA FOR DOSE CALCULATION IN ADAPTIVE PLANNING PERFORMANCE OF USING MV-CBCT IMAGES FOR 3DCRT PLANNING ON CMS XIO 3D PLANNING SYSTEM IMPROVEMENT OF SETUP ACCURACY IN IRRADIATION OF PROSTATE CANCER USING IGRT

abstract.text: We have developed a visualization environment to assist surgeons with therapy delivery inside the beating heart, in absence of direct vision. This system employs virtual reality techniques to integrate pre-operative anatomical models, real-time intra-operative imaging, and models of magnetically-tracked surgical tools (Figure 1 ). Methods: Visualization is enhanced via 3D dynamic cardiac models constructed from high-resolution preoperative MR or CT data and registered within the intra-operative imaging environment. In this paper, we report our experience with a feature-based registration technique to fuse the pre-and intra-operative data during an in vivo intracardiac procedure on a porcine subject. Satisfactory alignment of the pre-and intra-operative anatomy within the virtual reality environment is ensured through the registration of easily identifiable landmarks. Results: We present our initial experience in translating this work into the operating room and employing this system to guide typical intracardiac interventions. Discussion: We conclude that the integration of intra-operative imaging with virtual models of anatomy and surgical instruments is a key step to enable the successful implementation of minimally-invasive procedures inside the beating heart. Figure 1. Virtual reality environment showing intra-operative US, virtual tools, and pre-operative models during a minimallyinvasive intra-cardiac procedure.

Introduction: Four dimensional computed tomography (4D CT) is a very useful tool for assessing thoracic and abdominal tumor and normal tissue motion for treatment planning purposes. The objective of this talk is to describe the principles of 4D CT acquisition, ongoing developments to improve 4D CT image quality, and applications and limitations of 4D CT. Methods: 4D CT images are created by acquiring oversampled CT data simultaneously with a respiratory signal and reconstructing a number of 3D CT datasets. These 3D CT datasets are then correlated with a given respiratory displacement range or phase range to include respiratory motion into the images. First published on and commercially available in 2003, 4D CT is now a widely used imaging modality for radiotherapy. More recently, 4D cone-beam CT has also been demonstrated to be a useful tool to assist target localization prior to radiation delivery.

Since the inception of 4D CT, developments to improve image quality, predominantly to reduce artifacts due to respiratory irregularity, have been ongoing. Artifacts occur at an alarming rate in 4D CT, e.g. artifacts >4mm have been measured in over 90% (46/50) of retrospectively phase sorted patient 4D CT scans in our clinic. Efforts to reduce artifacts and improve image quality can be broadly classified into three groups: (1) improving the respiratory regularity of the patient through coaching, e.g. by using audiovisual biofeedback, (2) improving the data acquisition by selectively acquiring data during regular respiration only, and (3) improving post-processing methods. 4D CT produces an order of magnitude more data than 3D CT, thus creating an increase in image segmentation, planning, and storage. Some of the anatomic segmentation tasks can be automated through deformable image registration. Efforts in planning on 4D datasets are ongoing. An exciting application of 4D CT is for ventilation assessment, which potentially can yield ventilation images more quickly, cost effective, and with higher resolution than nuclear medicine studies. Validation of 4D CT for ventilation is therefore needed. Conclusions: 4D CT is useful for several modes of radiation delivery, including motion inclusive delivery, respiratory gated delivery, and tumor tracking delivery. 4D CT also serves as a tool to quantify tumor motion to determine if respiratory management is necessary during treatment delivery and also the appropriate management strategy. An important and often overlooked feature of 4D CT, is that it is only a snapshot of the anatomy at a specific time, but by using it for treatment planning, it is intended to be representative of the anatomy for days or weeks of treatment. Therefore, as respiratory motion changes from cycle-to-cycle, and changes in functional reserve capacity and patient pose cause daily variations in treatment position, systematic errors in target position estimation can occur with 4D delivery methods. This can be true even if a 4D CT is acquired immediately prior to treatment delivery. Accurate management of respiratory motion and novel delivery and image acquisition methods for 4D CT may however reduce these errors.

Introduction: Cone beam CT (CBCT) data gives information at the time of treatment on both anatomical detail and electron density of the tissue, using the Hounsfield Unit (HU) value. This allows comparison of the dose delivered with the planned dose from the conventional CT (convCT) scan. To date there have been very few studies on the accuracy of CBCT data for dose calculation. Yang[1], Ding[2] and van Zijtfeld [3] report good agreement for convCT and CBCT dose calculations on small patient samples, but there has not been direct comparison of measured and CBCT calculated doses. However, measured doses remain the "gold standard". Van Esch, assessing Eclipse AAA algorithm, reports point dose measurements in thorax phantom within 5% of calculated [4]. This work investigates the accuracy of the kilovoltage CBCT data for dose calculation, by comparison with measured values, as a part of a larger study on adaptive radiotherapy using CBCT. Methods: Kilovoltage CBCT images were obtained using the On-Board imager (OBI) integrated in Varian iX linac, for full fan and half fan modes, corresponding to small and large fields of view. Calibration of the HU was performed following manufacturer's recommendations. GE Lightspeed scanner was used for the convCT scans. Dose measurements were made on a simple block phantom, made up of water-equivalent, lung and bone slabs, using 0.6cm3 chamber, at both 6MV and 18MV. Doses were calculated for the three CT configurations, using Eclipse AAA algorithm. Results: CT scans were assessed using a central profile, as shown in figure 1 for the large field of view CBCT. Figure 2 shows all CT scan HU number profiles. Measured point dose results for fields with inhomogeneities show differences up to 8% from calculated, using convCT and CBCT for full and half fan.

Siemens ARTISTE Linear Accelerator with MV-CBCT provides image sized 27cm x 27cm and 40cm x 40cm (off-set model) commonly used for the 3D registration process to verify the patient treatment position in Image Guided Radiotherapy Technique (IGRT) for before, during or after the external beam treatment. With less than 5 minutes scan and reconstruction time, a series of MV-CT images can be created. In this study, MV-CBCT image quality has analysed with comparing different scanning protocols with giving different gantry rotation angles and monitor units to the scanning processes. Based on good image quality and reliable result of electron density calibration, the MV CBCT images tested for direct planning process on CMS XiO 3D planning system. The planning result compared with normal planning process carried by kV-CT images especially for same patients with high density artificial tissues involved around the treatment region. Methods: Electron density calibration phantom is used for MV-CBCT scans given 4~8 MUs for 200 degree gantry rotation scan and 8~15MUs for 360 degree gantry rotation scans. The CT HU numbers are read from CMS XiO after the images transferred into the planning system, and 3D planning cases selected patients with artificial tissues such as artificial teeth for head/neck or hip prosthesis for prostates. The dose delivered by the planning results was tested with by ionization measurement using IMRT phantom. Results: Electron density calibration shows well reliability and reproducibility on MV-CBCT tissue equivalent to electron density responded by planning images. The calibrated electron density curves indicated with more linear shape compared with kV-CT electron density curves. The result for low MU scans indicated with higher reading noises however, there no noticeable curve shape changes. Compare the electron density calibration for different scan doses, the calibration curves were shown no significant differences. The planning calculated effective depth for imhomogeneity tissues on each beam in 3D was satisfied accurate. Compare same planning cases performed by using normal kV-CT images, for the cases involved with high density artificial tissues in the treatment region, the accuracy shows the advantages using MV-CBCT image. This result has approved by reviewing the point dose ionization measurement via IMRT phantom. Discussion: Obviously, improved image reconstruction technique and software smoothing process provides more uniformity and reliability to the reconstructed MV-CBCT images. This improvement is potentially providing the chance for MV-CBCT image can be used for direct 3D treatment planning processes. The testing result also shows that the current version of CMS 3D planning system is capable to handle the independent 3D planning calculation with using MV-CBCT images. The planning calculation results were less perturbed by high density artificial tissues on GTV contouring, and reduced the uncertainty level on tissue density calculation. Although the disadvantage of using MV-CBCT images for 3D planning could be the lower image contrast with more difficulties to determine the GTV especially for some prostate cases. However, with involve multiple images fusion when GTV contouring such as MRI, PET-CT or even kV-CT would able to make this

body_text.text: Discussion: For the simple inhomogeneity block phantom, convCT profile is close to expected. Both CBCT profiles show good agreement for the lung tissue, but very poor for the bone, with normal tissue values significantly different from the expected zero. Full fan scan gives better results than half fan scan. Further investigation will consider the effect of scatter on the calibration method for half fan. Point dose calculations show significant difference from measured for inhomogeneities with Eclipse AAA algorithm. The extreme cases in this simple phantom will be extended with further work on anthropomorphic phantom such as "Elvis" pelvis phantom. Conclusion: CBCT data provides much information for dose assessment. Further work on calibration and comparison with measured doses will determine the dosimetric tolerance possible. This is part of a larger project looking at the role of adaptive planning. This work was supported by NSW Cancer Institute Clinical research grant.

Conclusion: MV-CBCT can provide reliable electron density calibration, the image quality potentially good enough to be used to perform direct 3D planning process. We can summarize a nonlinear differential equation system of order 3: Introduction: Over the years, the role of the right ventricle (RV) of the heart in maintaining normal overall haemodynamics and interventricular dependence has become much more recognized. Measurements of the shape and the regional deformation of not only the left ventricle (LV), but also the RV, are essential for quantifying normal and impaired cardiac function. Currently, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is considered to be the most accurate method for assessing the size and function of the RV due to its excellent image quality and reproducibility, especially in right ventricular dysplasia. Cardiac Image Modeller (CIM), a software package developed by the Auckland MRI Research Group (AMRG), enables rapid visualization and analysis of MR images in 3D space and through time. Through interactive fitting of a deformable model of the LV to MR images, mass, volume and ejection fraction of the LV at end-diastole and end-systole can be obtained (see Fig. 1 (a) & (b)). It is the aim of this study to extend the CIM interactive modelling techniques developed by AMRG to fast and efficient clinical analysis of both LV and RV deformation.

A geometric finite element model of both ventricles of an isolated arrested pig heart developed previously [1] consists of 88 elements, each with tricubic interpolation in circumferential, longitudinal and transmural coordinates. The large number of degrees of freedoms (DOFs) in this model may compromise the speed of clinical analysis. Thus, in order to reduce the number of DOFs, the model was set to be bicubic in circumferential and longitudinal coordinates, and linear in Table 1 .
